I once went three months without sleep. I got maybe half an hour to an hour total in a week during the first month, and by the end I would just completely space out in the middle of activities. It was like my brain would go to sleep but my body stayed awake, and it was only for five minute bursts or so. I experienced severe disruption in cognitive function, and it felt to me as though my brain was cutting out all mental processes that weren’t necessary for staying alive day today. I also definitely acted as though inebriated (lol). Due to the fact that I rarely get quality sleep and I am just now getting to a healthier sleep cycle, I imagine I am still recovering from the mental effects of that period, which was about 10 months ago.

I know what it’s like. I didn’t sleep for years. It was unimaginable, and no, it was NOT your normal insomnia. No matter what I did as therapies, it ended up generally making  the condition worse. I could work and work and work. but no matter how much work I did, my body wouldn’t seem to ever shut down to get away from the world and to heal mentally, spiritually and physically - it was literally killing me in all those ways.   I thought I had FFI (Fatal Familial Insomnia), or Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.  I did do something about it, took me years to achieve. Now I do sleep, but still it isn’t in the normal range. It was something out of the Twighlight Zone, something I could not relate to others, it was not real to them as something like that could not be easily fathomed.  I really thought I was going to die from lack of no sleep, as it was taking its toll on my body in many ways.

I got a neighbour with a young child that keeps on crying and crying..and when they're not screaming at each other, she puts on loud music.
Either way, I haven't slept well for 2 weeks. And I've started noticing that.

What happened first, is that I got irr- (I can't seem to figure out how to spell it. I genuienly can't. Loss of memory was supposed to be number two on the list. Either way, you know what I mean. Cranky)
I genuienly noticed I was só close to punching people several times. I would've never done it, ofcourse. But there was a rage I've never felt before. I originally work with kids, I'm the most tolerant person that I know in my friends-group.
But no matter friendly people in the aisle of the shop that whistle songs, no matter cuddling pigeons on a tree-branch, no matter toddlers that ask their moms for a toy, for the last 14 days, I just wanted to bite their faces off. Or scream loudly at them.

Then there's the loss of memory, beautifully demonstrated above, when I tried writing irr- and I still can't write it.
I've noticed I genuienly started switching words around.
'I have heared the child punching the wall again', became; 'I have hared the hild cunching the hall ahan."
"I am so tired, I need to sleep", became 'I mam so nired, I seen to sleep.'
The back babbit. (black rabbit) Creen Gristmastrees. The by is skue. ...And so on.
I've been calling Cynthia 'Chelsea' for days now and often just stop mid-sentence and forget what I was doing. Or I just 'wake up' while my head is hanging above the table, in mid-sleep (but sadly never a full sleep.)

Then, there's the fact that I'm hyper-alert. Each tiny noise is like a blasting gun next to my head. Like Swuidward (I kept writing it wrong, I know it's with a q, I just can't do this now, my brain doesn't do what I want..) I have my eyes wide-open after éách little noise that I hear.
I start shaking when I hear a car going by, I dig my nails into my hands with each midnight-cough that usually indicates the screaming will follow again...

Then there's hallucinating. I haven't gotten that far yet, but I have endless thoughts running through my mind, about bullshit that nobody cares about. Like a bull that needs a birthdaycake. Or a bird made of knifes, with fork-like-legs. Or cake with marbles. Cake with feathers. And so on. Pictures and/or ideas, like a gambling-machine, turning and turning in my head.
Which is very creative, but it's like torture when you want to sleep.

Then there's numbness. Apart from feeling exhausted and tense, I feel nothing. Or at least, I can't really feel it.
I went to a group and was told that everyone got a Christmas-present, except for me. Because I had been there for 2,8 months and not 3. That was too short. Everyone talked about what was in their present. They showed it and complained that it wasn't enough. And I just sat there. Later, other friends and people told me about their presents too.
I was sad, but I couldn't feel anything but a plain 'sad.' No real emotions.
One time, on thursday, it came out and I cried loudly. For 3 minutes. For a moment I felt great. Then the crying began on the other side of the wall and I was back to numb.

So many things have happened in the last days...people accidently breaking my items or handing me wonderfull christmas-gifts. Shocking things, like someone fainting or falling on the ice, with a bike.
I helped, sure. But thoughtlessly, no feelings. All I worry about is whether the kid starts crying or hitting the wall again. OR whether the mom starts screaming at him again. The neighbour two-apartments-down also hears it at night. And another woman has complaints, on the other side of the street. She's bothered by the smoking (just as I am, she smokes next to my window. But the noise is worse.)

Yesterday, 2 days after handing her a Christmascard, I went over to her and said; 'I'm sorry, I am bothered by your sounds. I can literally hear every word you say to your mom on the phone, to your (I didn't say it, but loudly barking) dog and to your (I didn't say it, but loudly screaming) child. Things to your mom about the couch, you telling the dog to come to you or you telling the child to put his shoes on. Could you try keeping it down?'
She then blew her smoke in my face (she was smoking) and said; 'Sure.'

Then I woke up this morning, to the most loud assortiment of noises I'd heard so far. Running, screaming, punching the wall, kicking the wall, jumping, dancing, singing, crying, screaming again. The child was going absolutely nuts and it sounded like she was cheering him on.
I think it's not a coïncidence and that this was on purpose. I re-arranged my room today, so that I can sleep in the other corner of the room. I hope it works, I am exhausted.

When I was much younger (maybe 7-8 in the first grade) I had a horrible insomnia problem which only recently weared out. The doctors referred to it mostly as a melatonin (the "mineral"/stimuli/whatever responsible for sleep) deficiency. I went 7 days without sleep and the night after that I did, I only got 2-4 hours. The beginning was fine mostly. Then I began seeing things like a ghostly image of my dog whom was alive and odd floating color things ( one being small Elmo heads with purple spirals for eyes). At this point I felt miserable. I believe I sorta passed out from exhaustion because I had no memory of going to sleep. My last awake memory was standing on my bed. I woke up and it seemed as if I had collapsed into a sitting position and the sun was a light somebody had just abruptly turned on. Throughout my time as an insomniac I had always straight A's and a low immune system. After the insomnia began to go away was when I acquired multiple medical conditions atop what I already had, which includes the general depression mentioned in this video and maintaining the low immune system.

Nice video, though I have to point out some obvious problems with the sleep deprivation studies and health effects. You need to consider the context of the person as a whole - that is, their intrapsychic reality, what it's like to be them, how they feel during the period of insomnia.

While insomnia, by itself - over a period of 10 or so days -  appears not to have any negative health effects, this is insomnia OUTSIDE THE LIVED WORLD. Insomnia + the daily stresses we encounter in a capitalist economy (and the competition/inattention it creates) could very well work together to precipitate disease in the body.

My record is 21 days with no sleep. Although, unlike the way its discussed in this video, the experience was utterly traumatizing. Would not recommend it. I lost 15 pounds, suffered intense anxiety, incessant paranoia, complete loss of appetite, compulsive urination, intermittent breaks in awareness, electric shocks in the brain (which is subjectively felt in that way) and a growing sense of it getting worse and worse until - a complete discombubulation of the psyche - the conscious mind vacating its position as director so the body can return itself to a state of physiological homeostasis. The mind that you find in such a dilemma - what we call psychosis - is essentially a medley of disparate self-states: the parts which made up "us" when we had the inner flashlight guiding the door to awareness.

Usually people would describe such an experience as a "nervous breakdown", and I guess it was. Changed me though for the better. If you are fortunate enough to get out of such situations - and thanks to modern drugs its perfectly possible - you can reassemble the pieces in a stronger, more self-aware and resourceful way.

Actually, that's a little untrue.  In psychology we watched an experiment in sleep deprivation.  Peter Tripp had stayed awake for the march of dimes, afterwards his wife said he was a different man, they ended up divorced.  He had great difficulty holding a marriage together.  I saw the raw black and white film about 10 years ago so I don't remember much of it.  The military also uses sleep deprivation to create a strong bond between soldiers and an easy way to get people to do the things they need to do in order to train.  I think that there may be long term effects, but it's up to science to research.

I have been running sleep deprivation experiments on myself since I was 13 years old I am 25 now. I have had no long term or serious negative effects from this and I have had my body examined by medical professionals over the years. Not to say this is for everyone just saying with the right training and dedication sleep deprivation has proved to be beneficial to my overall well being and productivity. This is also not to say that over the years i have not experienced some ill effects, but none of these ill effects have been hazardous to my health just an inconvenience at times such as the hallucinations. My point in all this is that we humans are very unique and a test done to a few does not display the proper results for the whole. Don't believe everything they tell you research and discover the truth for yourself  :)

this is what happens if you stay awake too long:
Russian researchers in the late 1940s kept five people awake for fifteen days using an experimental gas based stimulant. They were kept in a sealed environment to carefully monitor their oxygen intake so the gas didn't kill them, since it was toxic in high concentrations. This was before closed circuit cameras so they had only microphones and 5 inch thick glass porthole sized windows into the chamber to monitor them. The chamber was stocked with books, cots to sleep on but no bedding, running water and toilet, and enough dried food to last all five for over a month.

The test subjects were political prisoners deemed enemies of the state during World War II.

Everything was fine for the first five days; the subjects hardly complained having been promised (falsely) that they would be freed if they submitted to the test and did not sleep for 30 days. Their conversations and activities were monitored and it was noted that they continued to talk about increasingly traumatic incidents in their past, and the general tone of their conversations took on a darker aspect after the 4 day mark.

After five days they started to complain about the circumstances and events that lead them to where they were and started to demonstrate severe paranoia. They stopped talking to each other and began alternately whispering to the microphones and one way mirrored portholes. Oddly they all seemed to think they could win the trust of the experimenters by turning over their comrades, the other subjects in captivity with them. At first the researchers suspected this was an effect of the gas itself...

After nine days the first of them started screaming. He ran the length of the chamber repeatedly yelling at the top of his lungs for 3 hours straight, he continued attempting to scream but was only able to produce occasional squeaks. The researchers postulated that he had physically torn his vocal cords. The most surprising thing about this behavior is how the other captives reacted to it... or rather didn't react to it. They continued whispering to the microphones until the second of the captives started to scream. The 2 non-screaming captives took the books apart, smeared page after page with their own feces and pasted them calmly over the glass portholes. The screaming promptly stopped.

So did the whispering to the microphones.

After 3 more days passed. The researchers checked the microphones hourly to make sure they were working, since they thought it impossible that no sound could be coming with 5 people inside. The oxygen consumption in the chamber indicated that all 5 must still be alive. In fact it was the amount of oxygen 5 people would consume at a very heavy level of strenuous exercise. On the morning of the 14th day the researchers did something they said they would not do to get a reaction from the captives, they used the intercom inside the chamber, hoping to provoke any response from the captives they were afraid were either dead or vegetables.

They announced: "We are opening the chamber to test the microphones; step away from the door and lie flat on the floor or you will be shot. Compliance will earn one of you your immediate freedom."

To their surprise they heard a single phrase in a calm voice response: "We no longer want to be freed."

Debate broke out among the researchers and the military forces funding the research. Unable to provoke any more response using the intercom it was finally decided to open the chamber at midnight on the fifteenth day.

The chamber was flushed of the stimulant gas and filled with fresh air and immediately voices from the microphones began to object. 3 different voices began begging, as if pleading for the life of loved ones to turn the gas back on. The chamber was opened and soldiers sent in to retrieve the test subjects. They began to scream louder than ever, and so did the soldiers when they saw what was inside. Four of the five subjects were still alive, although no one could rightly call the state that any of them in 'life.'

The food rations past day 5 had not been so much as touched. There were chunks of meat from the dead test subject's thighs and chest stuffed into the drain in the center of the chamber, blocking the drain and allowing 4 inches of water to accumulate on the floor. Precisely how much of the water on the floor was actually blood was never determined. All four 'surviving' test subjects also had large portions of muscle and skin torn away from their bodies. The destruction of flesh and exposed bone on their finger tips indicated that the wounds were inflicted by hand, not with teeth as the researchers initially thought. Closer examination of the position and angles of the wounds indicated that most if not all of them were self-inflicted.

The abdominal organs below the ribcage of all four test subjects had been removed. While the heart, lungs and diaphragm remained in place, the skin and most of the muscles attached to the ribs had been ripped off, exposing the lungs through the ribcage. All the blood vessels and organs remained intact, they had just been taken out and laid on the floor, fanning out around the eviscerated but still living bodies of the subjects. The digestive tract of all four could be seen to be working, digesting food. It quickly became apparent that what they were digesting was their own flesh that they had ripped off and eaten over the course of days.

Most of the soldiers were Russian special operatives at the facility, but still many refused to return to the chamber to remove the test subjects. They continued to scream to be left in the chamber and alternately begged and demanded that the gas be turned back on, lest they fall asleep...

To everyone's surprise the test subjects put up a fierce fight in the process of being removed from the chamber. One of the Russian soldiers died from having his throat ripped out, another was gravely injured by having his testicles ripped off and an artery in his leg severed by one of the subject's teeth. Another 5 of the soldiers lost their lives if you count ones that committed suicide in the weeks following the incident.

In the struggle one of the four living subjects had his spleen ruptured and he bled out almost immediately. The medical researchers attempted to sedate him but this proved impossible. He was injected with more than ten times the human dose of a morphine derivative and still fought like a cornered animal, breaking the ribs and arm of one doctor. When heart was seen to beat for a full two minutes after he had bled out to the point there was more air in his vascular system than blood. Even after it stopped he continued to scream and flail for another 3 minutes, struggling to attack anyone in reach and just repeating the word "MORE" over and over, weaker and weaker, until he finally fell silent.

The surviving three test subjects were heavily restrained and moved to a medical facility, the two with intact vocal cords continuously begging for the gas demanding to be kept awake...

The most injured of the three was taken to the only surgical operating room that the facility had. In the process of preparing the subject to have his organs placed back within his body it was found that he was effectively immune to the sedative they had given him to prepare him for the surgery. He fought furiously against his restraints when the anesthetic gas was brought out to put him under. He managed to tear most of the way through a 4 inch wide leather strap on one wrist, even through the weight of a 200 pound soldier holding that wrist as well. It took only a little more anesthetic than normal to put him under, and the instant his eyelids fluttered and closed, his heart stopped. In the autopsy of the test subject that died on the operating table it was found that his blood had triple the normal level of oxygen. His muscles that were still attached to his skeleton were badly torn and he had broken 9 bones in his struggle to not be subdued. Most of them were from the force his own muscles had exerted on them.

The second survivor had been the first of the group of five to start screaming. His vocal cords destroyed he was unable to beg or object to surgery, and he only reacted by shaking his head violently in disapproval when the anesthetic gas was brought near him. He shook his head yes when someone suggested, reluctantly, they try the surgery without anesthetic, and did not react for the entire 6 hour procedure of replacing his abdominal organs and attempting to cover them with what remained of his skin. The surgeon presiding stated repeatedly that it should be medically possible for the patient to still be alive. One terrified nurse assisting the surgery stated that she had seen the patients mouth curl into a smile several times, whenever his eyes met hers.

When the surgery ended the subject looked at the surgeon and began to wheeze loudly, attempting to talk while struggling. Assuming this must be something of drastic importance the surgeon had a pen and pad fetched so the patient could write his message. It was simple. "Keep cutting."

The other two test subjects were given the same surgery, both without anesthetic as well. Although they had to be injected with a paralytic for the duration of the operation. The surgeon found it impossible to perform the operation while the patients laughed continuously. Once paralyzed the subjects could only follow the attending researchers with their eyes. The paralytic cleared their system in an abnormally short period of time and they were soon trying to escape their bonds. The moment they could speak they were again asking for the stimulant gas. The researchers tried asking why they had injured themselves, why they had ripped out their own guts and why they wanted to be given the gas again.

Only one response was given: "I must remain awake."

All three subject's restraints were reinforced and they were placed back into the chamber awaiting determination as to what should be done with them. The researchers, facing the wrath of their military 'benefactors' for having failed the stated goals of their project considered euthanizing the surviving subjects. The commanding officer, an ex-KGB instead saw potential, and wanted to see what would happen if they were put back on the gas. The researchers strongly objected, but were overruled.

In preparation for being sealed in the chamber again the subjects were connected to an EEG monitor and had their restraints padded for long term confinement. To everyone's surprise all three stopped struggling the moment it was let slip that they were going back on the gas. It was obvious that at this point all three were putting up a great struggle to stay awake. One of subjects that could speak was humming loudly and continuously; the mute subject was straining his legs against the leather bonds with all his might, first left, then right, then left again for something to focus on. The remaining subject was holding his head off his pillow and blinking rapidly. Having been the first to be wired for EEG most of the researchers were monitoring his brain waves in surprise. They were normal most of the time but sometimes flat lined inexplicably. It looked as if he were repeatedly suffering brain death, before returning to normal. As they focused on paper scrolling out of the brainwave monitor only one nurse saw his eyes slip shut at the same moment his head hit the pillow. His brainwaves immediately changed to that of deep sleep, then flatlined for the last time as his heart simultaneously stopped.

The only remaining subject that could speak started screaming to be sealed in now. His brainwaves showed the same flatlines as one who had just died from falling asleep. The commander gave the order to seal the chamber with both subjects inside, as well as 3 researchers. One of the named three immediately drew his gun and shot the commander point blank between the eyes, then turned the gun on the mute subject and blew his brains out as well.

He pointed his gun at the remaining subject, still restrained to a bed as the remaining members of the medical and research team fled the room. "I won't be locked in here with these things! Not with you!" he screamed at the man strapped to the table. "WHAT ARE YOU?" he demanded. "I must know!"

The subject smiled.

"Have you forgotten so easily?" The subject asked. "We are you. We are the madness that lurks within you all, begging to be free at every moment in your deepest animal mind. We are what you hide from in your beds every night. We are what you sedate into silence and paralysis when you go to the nocturnal haven where we cannot tread."

The researcher paused. Then aimed at the subject's heart and fired. The EEG flatlined as the subject weakly choked out, "So... nearly... free..."

Update on this subject: Scientists just recently discovered that the core reason for sleep is for the body to be able to faster '' wash '' out waste that builds up in our brain as we use it. 
This is also why the brain shows just as much activity when we are asleep as when we are awake. Because when we sleep the cleaning process of the brain basically goes into speed mode. 
This also explains why too little sleep leads to worsened memory and other such things. It can also lead to other sicknesses such as Alzheimer's later in life.

This is still being studied by researchers. But the most likely cause found is in cell division where cells "cut of" telomeres. Telomeres are disposable buffers blocking the ends of the chromosomes and are consumed during cell division and replenished by an enzyme, or the telomerase reverse transcriptase. So as the telomeres get shorter, your cells begin to not be able to multiply without cutting off genetic information. Essentially, we're programmed to die in our cellular structure.

@njm1112 Actually, you are at an altered state of consciousness for the first stage or two of the sleep cycle. The deeper into the NREM sleep stages you go, the harder it is to wake you up and in stage four, it's almost impossible. But when you move in to REM sleep, which comes after stage 4, your body becomes completely paralyzed. That is the stage your dreaming takes place. FYI: fatal familial insomnia is a degenerative prion disease caused by a heretable mutation in the gene encoding the protein PrPSc which causes symptoms including insomnia, autonomic instability, dementia, and death.  The other symptoms are sequelae of neuronal death, not necessarily the insomnia itself.  Other prion diseases also cause dementia and death (i.e. variant CJD or "mad cow disease", CJD, or gerstmann-straussler-scheinker disease).  Translation:  check yo facts son!

No, to get a full nights restful sleep of 6-8 hours your body needs to go through at least 2 REM, Non-REM, cycles. During sleep, the body cycles between non-REM and REM sleep. Typically, people begin the sleep cycle with a period of non-REM sleep followed by a very short period of REM sleep. Dreams generally occur in the REM stage of sleep. During the deep stages of NREM sleep, the body repairs and regenerates tissues, builds bone and muscle, and appears to strengthen the immune system.

Our bodies have a tendency to not like foreign objects inside of them. When bugs bite us, small amounts of their venom or saliva enter the surface of your skin. When this happens, our bodies response is to release histamine to cause proportional inflammation in the immediate area. This is meant to quarantine the foreign cells so our body can target them more easily with anti-bodies. Thats why you should never scratch a bug bite, as it releases the foreign cells into your blood supply.

This vertical temperature trend is a consequence of 1) lower atmospheric pressure at higher altitude and 2) heating that takes place at the bottom of the troposphere rather than at the top. The rate of change of temperature with height, is called the lapse rate by meteorologists. In the troposphere, the lowest layer of the Earth’s atmosphere, temperature decreases with altitude. This trend does not continue into the layer above.

What you're experiencing Sleep Paralysis. It's not dangerous, but as you've probably noted, it's incredibly scary. Anyways, while sleeping, your body produces hormones to prevent your body from acting out your dreams (i.e. running the marathon you're dreaming about). Sometimes, when you wake up, your body hasn't stopped pumping out these hormones, and so you experience that "I can't move a muscle" feeling. 

If it really bothers you, I suggest you read up about it, or talk to your doctor :)

The weird feeling you get when you hit your funny bone is because you're actually hitting the ulnar nerve. It runs from your neck, all the way down to the hand. It's protected by bones, muscles and ligaments for most of the journey but there's a small gap (called the cubital tunnel) where it's only protected by soft tissue like skin and fat. When you hit the nerve in this gap, it compresses it against the bone and causes numbness, tingling and pain.

Oh that's easy. Women get their period because the eggs that are stored in our ovaries are meant for sexual reproduction (Getting Pregnant), but when that does not happen, then the eggs die (menstrual cycle). This is a monthly cycle when this happens (usually 28 days). New eggs develop, if they don't get fertilized, then they die and then new eggs are developed.

And the cramps are just muscles contracting during this cycle.

So basically, in a nut shell, women are here to procreate EVERY MONTH.

We sigh regularly to keep our lungs open and recruited. We always maintain a certain level of air in our lungs known as FRC (functional residual capacity), sighing resets that level. Our breathing pattern, rate and volume, is never consistent and every once and awhile our breathing requires a reset and a sigh does that bringing us to a baseline level again.

It's when something unfamiliar touches your skin, which is super sensitive especially in certain parts of your body (lips, head, down there, etc.). It's a form of security or safety.
